JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, DECEMBER 13, 1957

62ND YEAR

Dean Admits Greeks Martin New JHU Trustee;
Have Selection Right Head Of Federal Reserve
"I believe that fraternity membership should primarily be determined by the people who belong to the
fraternities."
This was the answer Dr. G. Wilson Shaffe-r, Dean of
the Homewood Schools, gave to a News-Letter question
concerning a report by a committee of the National Interfraternity Conference criticizing "planned attempts to reduce Greek-letter societies to a position of impotence,
if not to eliminate them entirely" through anti-discrimination "agitation".
University Policy
Dean Shaffer said that the
University accepts people according to their intellectual
standing. But he recognized the
right to let fraternities choose
their members in the way they
wish.
The Interfraternity Conference
was held in Colorado Springs,
Colorado and the report was delivered at that time. Francis S.
Van Derbur, conference chairman, called the report "a wellconsidered document by some of
the finest minds in the fraternity
system." Van Derbur is the father of Marilyn Van Derbur,
1958 "Miss America."
Universities Rapped
The report rapped the universities of Massachusetts, New
Mexico, Oregon, Washington
and Kansas City, and Lewis and
Clark Colleges, as schools which
have announced they will not
permit fraternities which prohibit membership on the basis of
race, color and creed.
Amherst College and the State
University of New York were
criticized for ordering social fraternities to revise their charters
or leave campus.
Arthur Davenport, fraternity
business manager for Amherst
College, said, "If anyone is attending Amherst College, he is
worthy of being a part of the
social structure of the college;
the boys should have the right
to choose the companions with
whom they live without artificial
barriers being imposed from the
outside."

Libby to 'Speak
At Seminar Here
• About Tritium
Dr. W. F. Libby will speak
the Hopkins Geophysical
Seminar today at 4. p.m- in Latrobe 307.
Dr. Libby, member of the
Atomic Energy Commission and
the Geophysical Laboratory, will
Speak on the topic of "Tritium
Hydrology."
He was formerly a professor
At the University of Chicago,
Where he contributed to the research of atomic energy. He is
more popularly known for his
discovery of the uses of Carbon
14 for the dating of all organic
substances.
All Things Take Ca.14
This substance, Carbon 14, is
absorbed by all living things,
plants, animals and human beings. When the living thing dies,
the absorbtion of Carbon 14
stops.
At this time Carbon 14 begins
to disintegrate at the rate of
one half each 5,580 years. The
rate of disintegration can be
calculated exactly.
20,000 Years' Evidence
Since all objects contain a
known amount of Carbon 14 and
lose this carbon at a specific
rate, Dr. Libby reasoned that
ancient objects could be dated
by determining their present
content of Carbon 14. By this
method definite proof has been

Mellow Music
By Orchestra,
Choir Dec. 20
This year's annual undergraduate Christmas Assembly,
sponsored by the Student Council, will be held in Shriver Hall
Auditorium Friday, Dec. 20 at
10 a.m.
According to Osmar P. Steinwald, Director of Student Music
at the Hopkins, the program will
feature "appropriate Christmas
music on the sacred side" by the
Johns Hopkins Orchestra, under
the direction of Hugo Weisgall,
and the Johns Hopkins Glee Club,
under the direction of James
Mitchell.
Patterson Choir
Guests at the assembly, according to Steinwald, will be the
prize-winning choir of Patterson
Park High School in Baltimore,
under the direction of Robert
Johnson.
Each group will sing selections
of its own. There will be a combined singing of Christmas
Carols by everyone present, according to Steinwald.
Dr. Chester L. Wickwire, Executive Secretary of the Hopkins
YMCA, will deliver the invocation.
Freshmen To Decorate
Tony Salem, President of the
Student Council, explained that
the freshman class is responsible
for decorating Shriver for the
Assembly. He pointed out that
decorations will be paid for by
the Council.
"The decorating of Shriver will
be the first duty to be carried
out by the newly-elected freshman class officers," commented
Salem, adding that a committee
has been formed and is making
preparations.
"We hope for a good attendante at this, the last Hopkins
Assembly of 1957," he added.

AD Takes Cup,
Ousting Phi Ep
From Top Slot
Alpha Delta Phi won the Bowman Cup for the outstanding
social fraternity for the scholastic year of 1956-57, Interfraternity Board President Gil
Decker announced this week.
"Alpha Delta Phi had a pretty
outstanding
record,"
Decker
commented.
Criteria Cited
The Cup is awarded on three
criteria: scholastic achievement
(Alpha Delt ranked seventh out
of thirteen fraternities), social
services to the Baltimore community
and
extra-curricular
leadership and participation.
To win the Cup, a fraternity
must compile a total number of
points greater than that of any
other fraternity in all three categories combined.
"Worked Hard"
Alpha Delt president Rue
Helsel exclaimed, "I really don't
know what to say except we are
truly pleased. ...We worked hard
for it to make up for our not
even getting a Certificate last
year. We are very happy."
Only six fraternities including
Alpha Delt submitted lists of
members in activities and thus
were the only ones eligible for
the Cup. Alpha Epsilon Pi, Alpha
Tau Omega, Phi Epsilon Pi, Phi
Gamma Delta and Phi Kappa
Psi each received a Bowman
Certificate of Merit,
AD's First Time
The Cup award system began
in 1951. That year and the next,
certificates only were awarded.
In 1953 Phi Ep won it, was tied
by Delta Upsilon in '54, and
copped it for the next two years.
The 1956-'57 award marks the
first time Alpha Delt has won
it and the first time Phi Ep has
not.
Decker noted the "unfair"
system of totaling points and
said the MB would try to change
"the entire system for awarding the Cup," probably by taking
away the limitation on the number of points-a fraternity can receive for extra-curricular leadership and participation.

William McChesney Martin, Jr., chairman of the
Federal Reserve Board, has become a member of the
Board of Trustees of the Johns Hopkins ,University, according to an announcement made this week by Carlyle
Barton, Chairman of the Board.
In his announcement Mr. Barton said, "Mr. Martin
has an intimate knowledge of American education ranging
from the secondary level to graduate studies. He has gained
this understanding from his activities with the Berry
Schools, Potomac School, The Foreign Service Educational

IFB Modulates
Way to Compute
Grade Averages'
A revision of rules relating to
the computation of a scholastic
average for fraternities was the
chief business of the Inter-Fraternity Board's Friday meeting.
According to the change, averages hereafter will be based
upon the scholastic average of a
fraternity's active members for
a given year plus those of any
pledges who had pledged for any
length of time that year and
who had returned the following
year still as pledges,
This differs from the old method which held that averages
should be based 'upon those of
all active members plus those of
anyone who has pledged two
weeks or more,
The advantage which this
change will bring, according to
Gil Decker, lies in the fact that
it eliminates the imperfection
of including in future averages,
averages of pledges who dropped
out of school or from the fraternity after a few weeks as a
pledge.
Gil Decker also announced
that there has been a revision
in the academic standings of the
fraternities.
The revision was'necessitated
when it was determined that
Alpha Tau Omega had not included all its members in the
roster submitted for determination of the grade averages.
With the revision, ATO passed
Beta Theta Pi and Phi Sigma
Delta to rank fourth among fraternities with an average of 5.
Phi Alpha, Phi Epsilon Pi, and
Alpha Epsilon Pi have the highest averages, respectively. The
revision also placed ATO among
the IFB fraternities above the
all-men's average.

Foundation and other schools
with which he has been associated.
"Great Value" To Hopkins
"He is well known for his
ability in administration and
public leadership," Barton conUntied. "His educational and administrative background will be
of great value to us as Johns
Hopkins continues to meet the
challenges we face in training
young people to become leaders
in this increasingly complex
world."
Mr. Martin was appointed as
Chairman, Board of Governors
of the Federal Reserve System in
April 1951, reappointed as chairman in 1955 and again appointed
for a fourteen year .term beginning February 1, 1956.
Yale Graduate
Graduating from Yale University in 1928, he studied law at
Benton College in St. Louis and
did part-time graduate study
at Columbia University between
1931 and 1937.
After graduating from Yale in
1928 he worked as a bank clerk
in St. Louis and served as the

Johnson Delivers
Series' First Talk
In Shriver Hall

The first of this year's University Lectures sponsored by
The Johns Hopkins University
was held Wednesday in Shriver
Hall and featured Dr. Ellis Johnson in a speech entitled "The
Relation of Operations Research
to the World Crisis in Science
and Technology."
Dr. Johnson is director of the
Operations Research Office in
Chevy Chase, an Army-contract
research organization administered by Johns Hopkins University.
Dr. Johnson has.been director
of ORO since its beginning in
1948. Born in Quincy, Mass., he
received his academic training
from the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology. Prior to World
War II he held civilian positions
at MIT, the Bell Telephone Company, the U. S. Coast and Geoweekends, each of which would detic Survey, the Carnegie Infete the parents of two of the stitution of Washington and the
undergraduate classes, w,as dis- Naval Ordnance Laboratory.
cussed.
During the war, he served in
the U. S. Navy as Lt. Commander
and Commander. He made g'eat
contributions to the war effort
by utilizing the techniques- of operations research. The research
group under his command devised the "degaussing" system of
neutralizing ships against magnetic mines and later they
planned the massive mine blockade of Japan's Inland Sea which
nearly halted Japanese shipping
in 1945.

To Coordinate And Help:
Student Council Goals
"The purposes of the Student
Council are coordination of activities and helping the student
body," said Council President
Tony Salem during a discussion
of Council aims during Tuesday's
meeting in Levering Hall, at
which the newly-elected freshman class representatives were
present.
A review of Council objectives
was aired by various Council
members during discussion on
the possibility of a Council-sponsored bus trip and seminar. SC
vice-president Bill Morrill objected to the plan, saying, "The
purpose of our Council is not
entertainment for the students.
There is no need for it at the
Hopkins."
Honor Commission Chairman
Joel Woodey stated: "Although
other Student Councils might
provide such (outlets) for their
student bodies, some of the
(other colleges) are little more

than overgrown high schools.
Hopkins is not like this."
Gentleman's Code Committee
Chairman Erv Sekulow concurred
with Morrill and Woodey in saying that such "entertainment"
is "not the Council's job." He
called for more concentration on
Council-sponsored activities on
campus.
Salem stated that he felt campus activities were "most important," but added that he felt
the bus trip and seminar under
discussion would be "an added
aid to student understanding."
"I believe students would want
to participate," he commented.
Further discussion was postponed until the next Council
meeting.
Among other business conducted during Tuesday's Meeting
was the appointment of a committee to arrange Parents' Weekend next spring. Joe Jeziorski is
to head the committee.

committee will determine the
recipient.

Hate, Hate Mr. Claus
We paced the filthy tiles of our private inner sanctum
occupied in our favorite frivolity, the weekly hate session.
It usually takes the better part of the evening, but as
stated by an editor emeritus, "but then we hate a lot of
people." Our pupils dilated and gleamed, fangs glistened,
editorial venom oozed over pallid jowls. "Hate" bellowed
the News Editor; "despise" hissed the Managing Editor;
"a pox upon thee" whispered the shy, but intrepid, cub
reporter. "You're coming along well, stripling," remarked the Copy Editor to the cub. "Just put a bit more
yigor in it."
The Editors-in-Chief groveled for a three syllable
exclamation of abhorrence. "Execration," screeched one;
"Acrimony" howled his cohort. They grasped hands
firmly and retired to their dungeon to munch zwieback
and to contemplate the editorial navel.
"Nothing" uttered the Associate Editor in utter
amazement. "I just can't find a soul to hate this week."

The Job interview program,
open to seniors and graduate students, opened November 1 for
applicants with PH.D. degrees
and one month later for other
applicants. From then
until
March, excluding exam and vacation periods, representatives
from almost all major industries
and the government conduct interviews at -the Hopkins. Each
interviewer• sets a specific date
for his interview one year in advance.

Viewing the recent damage caused by an unfortunate
combination of the indefatigable Hopkins Spirit and a
heavy snowfall, it would appear that most students really
do hate this "hole," as the once-nightly "attitude checks"
would indicate.
We are referring to the rash of broken windows, indoor snowball and water fights, torn screens, day and
nightly ambushes in sundry places, and the general commotion aroused by a few inches of fluffy, coMpressible
proto-snowball.

62ND YEAR

Dean Admits Greeks Martin New JHU Trustee;
Have Selection Right Head Of Federal Reserve
"I believe that fraternity membership should primarily be determined by the people who belong to the
fraternities."
This was the answer Dr. G. Wilson Shaffe-r, Dean of
the Homewood Schools, gave to a News-Letter question
concerning a report by a committee of the National Interfraternity Conference criticizing "planned attempts to reduce Greek-letter societies to a position of impotence,
if not to eliminate them entirely" through anti-discrimination "agitation".
University Policy
Dean Shaffer said that the
University accepts people according to their intellectual
standing. But he recognized the
right to let fraternities choose
their members in the way they
wish.
The Interfraternity Conference
was held in Colorado Springs,
Colorado and the report was delivered at that time. Francis S.
Van Derbur, conference chairman, called the report "a wellconsidered document by some of
the finest minds in the fraternity
system." Van Derbur is the father of Marilyn Van Derbur,
1958 "Miss America."
Universities Rapped
The report rapped the universities of Massachusetts, New
Mexico, Oregon, Washington
and Kansas City, and Lewis and
Clark Colleges, as schools which
have announced they will not
permit fraternities which prohibit membership on the basis of
race, color and creed.
Amherst College and the State
University of New York were
criticized for ordering social fraternities to revise their charters
or leave campus.
Arthur Davenport, fraternity
business manager for Amherst
College, said, "If anyone is attending Amherst College, he is
worthy of being a part of the
social structure of the college;
the boys should have the right
to choose the companions with
whom they live without artificial
barriers being imposed from the
outside."

Libby to 'Speak
At Seminar Here
• About Tritium
Dr. W. F. Libby will speak
the Hopkins Geophysical
Seminar today at 4. p.m- in Latrobe 307.
Dr. Libby, member of the
Atomic Energy Commission and
the Geophysical Laboratory, will
Speak on the topic of "Tritium
Hydrology."
He was formerly a professor
At the University of Chicago,
Where he contributed to the research of atomic energy. He is
more popularly known for his
discovery of the uses of Carbon
14 for the dating of all organic
substances.
All Things Take Ca.14
This substance, Carbon 14, is
absorbed by all living things,
plants, animals and human beings. When the living thing dies,
the absorbtion of Carbon 14
stops.
At this time Carbon 14 begins
to disintegrate at the rate of
one half each 5,580 years. The
rate of disintegration can be
calculated exactly.
20,000 Years' Evidence
Since all objects contain a
known amount of Carbon 14 and
lose this carbon at a specific
rate, Dr. Libby reasoned that
ancient objects could be dated
by determining their present
content of Carbon 14. By this
method definite proof has been

Mellow Music
By Orchestra,
Choir Dec. 20
This year's annual undergraduate Christmas Assembly,
sponsored by the Student Council, will be held in Shriver Hall
Auditorium Friday, Dec. 20 at
10 a.m.
According to Osmar P. Steinwald, Director of Student Music
at the Hopkins, the program will
feature "appropriate Christmas
music on the sacred side" by the
Johns Hopkins Orchestra, under
the direction of Hugo Weisgall,
and the Johns Hopkins Glee Club,
under the direction of James
Mitchell.
Patterson Choir
Guests at the assembly, according to Steinwald, will be the
prize-winning choir of Patterson
Park High School in Baltimore,
under the direction of Robert
Johnson.
Each group will sing selections
of its own. There will be a combined singing of Christmas
Carols by everyone present, according to Steinwald.
Dr. Chester L. Wickwire, Executive Secretary of the Hopkins
YMCA, will deliver the invocation.
Freshmen To Decorate
Tony Salem, President of the
Student Council, explained that
the freshman class is responsible
for decorating Shriver for the
Assembly. He pointed out that
decorations will be paid for by
the Council.
"The decorating of Shriver will
be the first duty to be carried
out by the newly-elected freshman class officers," commented
Salem, adding that a committee
has been formed and is making
preparations.
"We hope for a good attendante at this, the last Hopkins
Assembly of 1957," he added.

AD Takes Cup,
Ousting Phi Ep
From Top Slot
Alpha Delta Phi won the Bowman Cup for the outstanding
social fraternity for the scholastic year of 1956-57, Interfraternity Board President Gil
Decker announced this week.
"Alpha Delta Phi had a pretty
outstanding
record,"
Decker
commented.
Criteria Cited
The Cup is awarded on three
criteria: scholastic achievement
(Alpha Delt ranked seventh out
of thirteen fraternities), social
services to the Baltimore community
and
extra-curricular
leadership and participation.
To win the Cup, a fraternity
must compile a total number of
points greater than that of any
other fraternity in all three categories combined.
"Worked Hard"
Alpha Delt president Rue
Helsel exclaimed, "I really don't
know what to say except we are
truly pleased. ...We worked hard
for it to make up for our not
even getting a Certificate last
year. We are very happy."
Only six fraternities including
Alpha Delt submitted lists of
members in activities and thus
were the only ones eligible for
the Cup. Alpha Epsilon Pi, Alpha
Tau Omega, Phi Epsilon Pi, Phi
Gamma Delta and Phi Kappa
Psi each received a Bowman
Certificate of Merit,
AD's First Time
The Cup award system began
in 1951. That year and the next,
certificates only were awarded.
In 1953 Phi Ep won it, was tied
by Delta Upsilon in '54, and
copped it for the next two years.
The 1956-'57 award marks the
first time Alpha Delt has won
it and the first time Phi Ep has
not.
Decker noted the "unfair"
system of totaling points and
said the MB would try to change
"the entire system for awarding the Cup," probably by taking
away the limitation on the number of points-a fraternity can receive for extra-curricular leadership and participation.

William McChesney Martin, Jr., chairman of the
Federal Reserve Board, has become a member of the
Board of Trustees of the Johns Hopkins ,University, according to an announcement made this week by Carlyle
Barton, Chairman of the Board.
In his announcement Mr. Barton said, "Mr. Martin
has an intimate knowledge of American education ranging
from the secondary level to graduate studies. He has gained
this understanding from his activities with the Berry
Schools, Potomac School, The Foreign Service Educational

IFB Modulates
Way to Compute
Grade Averages'
A revision of rules relating to
the computation of a scholastic
average for fraternities was the
chief business of the Inter-Fraternity Board's Friday meeting.
According to the change, averages hereafter will be based
upon the scholastic average of a
fraternity's active members for
a given year plus those of any
pledges who had pledged for any
length of time that year and
who had returned the following
year still as pledges,
This differs from the old method which held that averages
should be based 'upon those of
all active members plus those of
anyone who has pledged two
weeks or more,
The advantage which this
change will bring, according to
Gil Decker, lies in the fact that
it eliminates the imperfection
of including in future averages,
averages of pledges who dropped
out of school or from the fraternity after a few weeks as a
pledge.
Gil Decker also announced
that there has been a revision
in the academic standings of the
fraternities.
The revision was'necessitated
when it was determined that
Alpha Tau Omega had not included all its members in the
roster submitted for determination of the grade averages.
With the revision, ATO passed
Beta Theta Pi and Phi Sigma
Delta to rank fourth among fraternities with an average of 5.
Phi Alpha, Phi Epsilon Pi, and
Alpha Epsilon Pi have the highest averages, respectively. The
revision also placed ATO among
the IFB fraternities above the
all-men's average.

with which he has been associated.

Johnson Delivers
Series' First Talk
In Shriver Hall

The first of this year's University Lectures sponsored by
The Johns Hopkins University
was held Wednesday in Shriver
Hall and featured Dr. Ellis Johnson in a speech entitled "The
Relation of Operations Research
to the World Crisis in Science
and Technology."
Dr. Johnson is director of the
Operations Research Office in
Chevy Chase, an Army-contract
research organization administered by Johns Hopkins University.
Dr. Johnson has.been director
of ORO since its beginning in
1948. Born in Quincy, Mass., he
received his academic training
from the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology. Prior to World
War II he held civilian positions
at MIT, the Bell Telephone Company, the U. S. Coast and Geoweekends, each of which would detic Survey, the Carnegie Infete the parents of two of the stitution of Washington and the
undergraduate classes, w,as dis- Naval Ordnance Laboratory.
cussed.
During the war, he served in
the U. S. Navy as Lt. Commander
and Commander. He made g'eat
contributions to the war effort
by utilizing the techniques- of operations research. The research
group under his command devised the "degaussing" system of
neutralizing ships against magnetic mines and later they
planned the massive mine blockade of Japan's Inland Sea which
nearly halted Japanese shipping
in 1945.

To Coordinate And Help:
Student Council Goals
"The purposes of the Student
Council are coordination of activities and helping the student
body," said Council President
Tony Salem during a discussion
of Council aims during Tuesday's
meeting in Levering Hall, at
which the newly-elected freshman class representatives were
present.
A review of Council objectives
was aired by various Council
members during discussion on
the possibility of a Council-sponsored bus trip and seminar. SC
vice-president Bill Morrill objected to the plan, saying, "The
purpose of our Council is not
entertainment for the students.
There is no need for it at the
Hopkins."
Honor Commission Chairman
Joel Woodey stated: "Although
other Student Councils might
provide such (outlets) for their
student bodies, some of the
(other colleges) are little more

than overgrown high schools.
Hopkins is not like this."
Gentleman's Code Committee
Chairman Erv Sekulow concurred
with Morrill and Woodey in saying that such "entertainment"
is "not the Council's job." He
called for more concentration on
Council-sponsored activities on
campus.
Salem stated that he felt campus activities were "most important," but added that he felt
the bus trip and seminar under
discussion would be "an added
aid to student understanding."
"I believe students would want
to participate," he commented.
Further discussion was postponed until the next Council
meeting.
Among other business conducted during Tuesday's Meeting
was the appointment of a committee to arrange Parents' Weekend next spring. Joe Jeziorski is
to head the committee.
